results.title: Google, Microsoft sign up to 'kill switch' phones
results.content:
It's not just Apple customers who will be able to brick their phone.

Google and Microsoft will incorporate technology into the next versions of their mobile operating systems that allow users to lock and erase lost or stolen phones remotely.

The plan was announced on Thursday by New York attorney general Eric Schneiderman, which last year put pressure on Apple to introduce the feature.

The technology, which Mr Schneiderman refers to as a 'kill switch', makes the phone useless and reduces its resale value.

The moves by Google, which is behind the Android operating system, and Microsoft, which has its Windows operating system, follow a decision by Apple last year to add it to the iOS software behind the iPhone and iPad.

Since the technology was introduced, a report from a group of law enforcement agencies has shown robberies in New York City involving Apple products fell 19 per cent from a year earlier.

Mr Schneiderman called the commitments from Google and Windows a "giant steps toward consumer safety".

In just one year, the Secure Our Smartphones Initiative has made tremendous strides towards curtailing the alarming trend of violent smartphone theft.
results.abstract: It's not just Apple customers who will be able to brick their phone.

results.title: FCC to hit Chinese retailer with record fine over jammers
results.content:
The US Federal Communications Commission plans to issue the largest fine in its history against C.T.S. Technology, a Chinese electronics company that is accused of marketing signal jamming devices to American consumers.

The FCC said on Thursday that it applied the maximum fine allowed for a total of $34.9m, which reflects a penalty for each of the 285 models marketed to US consumers, reports Gina Chon, US regulatory correspondent.

Selling signal jammers to US consumers is illegal since it can disrupt communication on mobile phones, Wi-FI networks and GPS systems.

On its web site, C.T.S claimed that certain signal jammers were approved by the FCC, which is a false statement, the agency said. C.T.S also sold 10 high-powered signal jammers to undercover FCC staffers.

Travis LeBlanc, Acting Chief of the FCC's Enforcement Bureau, said in a statement:

All companies, whether domestic or foreign, are banned from marketing illegal jammers in the US.

Signal jammers present a direct danger to public safety, potentially blocking the communications of first responders. Operating a jammer is also illegal, and consumers who do so face significant civil and criminal penalties.

The FCC ordered C.T.S to stop marketing illegal signal jammers to US consumers and provide information about people in the US who want to purchase the devices.

C.T.S. did not immediately return a request for comment.
results.abstract: The US Federal Communications Commission plans to issue the largest fine in its history against C.T.S. Technology, a Chinese electronics company that is accused of marketing signal jamming devices to American consumers.

results.title: Bang & Olufsen pulls trigger on share sale
results.content:
Bang & Olufsen, the maker of high-end sound systems and televisions, has pulled the trigger on a share sale it had been mulling.

The Danish company said it will sell up to 3.9m new shares, an offering that Danske Bank and Nordea Bank will manage.

Bang & Olufsen, which lost money in the quarter to the end of February, is trying to reignite sales by luring a younger audience .

Proceeds from the sale will, according to the company, be used on new advertising and marketing as well as research and development.

More to follow
results.abstract: Bang & Olufsen, the maker of high-end sound systems and televisions, has pulled the trigger on a share sale it had been mulling.

results.title: Regulator signs off on US gas export project
results.content:
It's a US seal of approval that is likely to attract attention in Russia.

US energy regulators have approved a project by Sempra Energy to export liquefied natural gas from a facility in America - only the second such proposal to be granted.

The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said on Thursday that the project in Louisiana - in which France's GDF Suez and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial also own a stake - will:

Be capable of liquefying domestically produced natural gas for export, importing LNG and regasifying it for delivery to domestic markets, and importing foreign-sourced LNG for subsequent export.

The crisis in Ukraine has sharpened political appetite in the US to reduce the eastern European country's reliance on Russia for its natural gas.

Sempra has said that the facility will be operational in 2018. Cheniere Energy is the only other company to have won approval for an LNG export plant in the US.

More to follow.
results.abstract: It's a US seal of approval that is likely to attract attention in Russia.

results.title: Argentine stocks fall on bond talk worries
results.content:
Shares in Argentine companies are falling after the nation's cabinet chief reportedly said the government will not send a mission to New York to discuss debt repayments with so-called "holdout creditors" that could help the nation avert a looming default.

The benchmark Merval index opened 3.6 per cent lower Thursday morning.

Shares in Argentine energy company YPF fell as much as 6.7 per cent.

"There's no Argentine mission or committee going to New York," cabinet chief Jorge Capitanich told reporters in Buenos Aires today, according to Bloomberg.

This appeared to contradict comments by a lawyer representing Argentina in a New York court on Wednesday.

As the FT reported, Carmine Boccuzzi, of Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, the lawyer representing Argentina, said at a hearing before Thomas Griesa, a New York district judge:

The plan is to be here next week to negotiate with the holdouts.

The Argentine stock market has fluctuated heavily throughout the week after the US Supreme Court rejected an Argentine petition to reverse a legal ruling by a lower US court that forced Buenos Aires to pay holdout creditors before it makes its next payment to holders of restructured notes.

The next payment on those restructured securities is due June 30.
results.abstract: Shares in Argentine companies are falling after the nation's cabinet chief reportedly said the government will not send a mission to New York to discuss debt repayments with so-called "holdout creditors" that could help the nation avert a looming default.

results.title: Markit shares jump on US debut
results.content:
US stocks are drifting on Thursday, but those of financial data provider Markit have a clear direction on their debut.

Shares in the company climbed almost 10 per cent as they began trading in New York, rising as high as $26.71 after selling for $24 each on Wednesday night.

Having raised $1.28bn and with its stock providing it a fresh currency for acquisitions, analysts say Markit is in a better position to compete with rivals including Thomson Reuters and Bloomberg.

Markit, which is run by chief executive Lance Uggla, offers pricing across a series of different financial markets.
results.abstract: US stocks are drifting on Thursday, but those of financial data provider Markit have a clear direction on their debut.

results.title: GE offers transport alliance to seal Alstom deal
results.content:
And the battle goes on.

General Electric has unveiled a revised proposal to try and secure a deal for Alstom's energy assets, in an increasingly protracted bid battle with German engineering giant Siemens and Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy for the French national champion.

GE said on Thursday that it would create an alliance to support Alstom's transport business - including the sale of GE's rail signalling business to the French company - and, in energy, give the French government a preferred share that would grant it a veto over nuclear issues.

The US comglomerate also said it had committed to create 1,000 new jobs in France over the next three years - a committment that would be enforced through an independent auditor, with inancial penalties if the goal is not achieved.

GE is trying to fend off a complex joint bid from Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy and to win over senior French politicians to the merits of its bid for Alstom's prized energy business.

Said GE chief executive Jeff Immelt:

Our discussions with the French government over the past seven weeks have been productive.

As a result, we have reached agreements with Alstom's management that will create an alliance between our companies in both spirit and practice.

The alliance will retain and strengthen France's presence in the energy business and reinforce Alstom Transport.

It creates jobs, establishes headquarters decision-making in France and ensures that the Alstom name will endure.

Here's the detail from the statement:

  • The creation of two 50/50 joint ventures to strengthen France's and Alstom's presence in energy and support its energy transition, one in grid power and one in renewable energy.

  • Creation of 50/50 joint venture in global nuclear and French steam business, with the French government holding a preferred share giving it veto and other governance rights over issues related to security and technology of nuclear plants. In addition, the intellectual property related to Alstom's "Arabelle" nuclear steam turbine technology will be transferred to a special purpose vehicle wholly owned by the French government, allowing it to license the tech to third parties.

  • Create a global alliance in transportation, including the sale of GE's signalling business to Alstom and other collaboration agreements.
results.abstract:
And the battle goes on.

General Electric has unveiled a revised proposal to try and secure a deal for Alstom's energy assets, in an increasingly protracted bid battle with German engineering giant Siemens and Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy for the French national champion.

results.title: Philly Fed index beats expectations
results.content:
The Federal Reserve may have cut its forecast for growth this year, but there was further evidence on Thursday that the economy is rebounding from a weak first quarter.

An index of manufacturing in the Philadelphia area climbed to its highest level since September

The index from the Philadelphia branch of the Federal Reserve climbed to 17.8 from 15.4 in May. Economists had forecast the index would come in at 14.

June's increase is the fourth in a row, cementing confidence that the sector has recovered from the winter disruption.

The index also revealed pressure on both prices and the jobs market. Its employment index climbed 4 points, while a measure of prices paid jumped 12 points.
results.abstract: The Federal Reserve may have cut its forecast for growth this year, but there was further evidence on Thursday that the economy is rebounding from a weak first quarter.

results.title: Twitter to buy video site SnappyTV
results.content:
Twitter is venturing further into video.

The company is buying SnappyTV, a video sharing and editing website.

Snappy offers live clipping, editing and distribution of videos and is popular with corporate users, including companies that share content on Twitter.

Snappy promotes itself as enabling organizations to "rapidly create, distribute and measure real-time promotional messaging delivered via social media channels."

The acquisition broadens Twitter's video offer after it bought short film-sharing app Vine last year.

Twitter said:

As we continue to invest in video, it's important for us to provide tools that make it easy for TV broadcasters, businesses, and event producers to share high-quality videos. To that end, we've agreed to acquire SnappyTV.

SnappyTV's platform for live clipping, editing, and distribution is already widely used by brands and our media partners to share video clips on Twitter, both organically and via Twitter Amplify. Together, we've worked with the biggest content partners in the world to inject the best video content into Twitter's real-time conversation, straight from the TV to your mobile device.

Twitter added it would continue to invest in Snappy's product and "integrate it more tightly with Twitter."

results.title: BlackBerry surprise winner of one battle in 2014
results.content:
BlackBerry may have been vanquished in America's smartphone battle, but there is one contest it is unexpectedly winning so far in 2014.

The shares of the Canadian company have climbed just over 20 per cent this year. They were up 11 per cent before BlackBerry released its latest quarterly results on Thursday and have climbed a further 9 per cent in pre-market trading.

That's better than Apple's 15 per cent return this year, Lenovo's 7.5 per cent increase, Samsung's 3.6 per cent fall, and HTC's 5.7 per cent drop.

Analysts, though, say little of the stock's outperformance in 2014 is down to hopes for its traditional handset business. Its global market share is forecast to slip below 1 per cent this year, according to technology research firm IDC.

Instead, investors have been heartened by chief executive John Chen's cost cutting (operating expenses were down 57 per cent in the quarter to May 31 from a year earlier) and his effort to bolster BlackBerry's other divisions, including one that provides security for messaging on phones.

Colin Gillis, a technology analyst at BGC Securities, upgraded BlackBerry to a 'buy' from a 'sell' earlier this week, arguing that "we see the risk-reward in shares of BlackBerry turning favourable."

However, he also cautioned:

We continue to see Blackberry as a special situation distressed asset- a company struggling to turn its business around, so investors should brace themselves for share price volatility in both directions
results.abstract: BlackBerry may have been vanquished in America's smartphone battle, but there is one contest it is unexpectedly winning so far in 2014.
